Xiasi hounds wearing festive costumes to greet the approaching Chinese Lunar Year of the Dog.

The South China Morning Post's new office space in Times Square, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong.

The offices, stretched across six floors, are designed to enhance openness, connectivity and flexibility, while providing staff with an enjoyable environment in which to work.

Each floor has a uniquely themed social hub - an arcade, games room, cafe and yoga area - to promote interaction, allowing employees to collaborate cross-departmentally or alternatively to find a quiet, comfortable space for rest and relaxation. üì∑: SCMP

"Big Snake Mak" otherwise known as serpent salesman Mak Tai-kwong says the secret to Hong Kongers' long lifespan may be because of the tradition of drinking snake soup

The winter delicacy is said to help boost energy levels and improve the skin.

The over 120-year-old snake shop She Wong Lam in Sheung Wan, where Mak works, serves up about 100 bowls of freshly made snake soup a day. üì∑: James Wendilinger

A magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the Taiwanese city of Hualien late on Tuesday night, trapping dozens in collapsed buildings and damaging roads and bridges. At least four people have been killed and 200 injured.

Republic of Korea Air Force Black Eagles aerobatic team performing aerial display during a preview for the Singapore Airshow 2018. 
One of the jets skidded off a runway at Singapore's Changi Airport and burst into flames. The pilot escaped with minor injuries.

The airshow is open to public on 10 and 11 February. üì∑: AFP, Xinhua

Taking photographs of one of Hong Kong's most popular tourist spots has been banned. 
The "monster buildings" in Quarry Bay shot to fame after they were featured in one of the Transformers movies in 2015. Hordes of late-night, camera-wielding tourists have disturbed local residents.
Notices have been put up around the 2,200 flats telling tourists not to "take photos and video without prior approval." #hongkong #travel #photography #tourists #skyscraper #highrise

Asian elephants are an endangered species. 
Some 300 of them live in Xishuangbanna, in southwest China's Yunnan province. 
Armed policeman have been deployed to patrol the forest area since 1996, protecting the species from poachers. 
Thanks to government and activist action, the elephant population here has doubled in the past 20 years. But as the number rises, the creatures increasingly invade local villages and destroy the property of residents. 
However, it remains illegal to hurt the elephants. üì∏: Visual China Group

#elephant #asianelephant #china #nature #wildlife #poachers

Three ostriches ran amok on a busy road in Guangxi Zhuang in China, causing chaos for motorists as pedestrians scrambled to catch the wild animals. 
#china #asia #wildlife #ostrich #traffic

High-speed trains wait to be maintained in Wuhan, central China's Hubei Province.

About 2.98 billion trips are expected to be made during 2018's Spring Festival travel rush, commonly known as Chunyun. It started on Thursday and will last till March 12. The Spring Festival, or Chinese Lunar New Year, falls on February 16 this year. üì∏: Xinhua, Xiao Yijiu/zwx

#cny #china #chinesenewyear #springfestival #chunyun #holiday
Cold resistance training: Armed police in #China's northeastern #Heilongjiang province train in brutal sub-zero temperatures. üí™üèº

Port of the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge in Zhuhai, south #China's Guangdong province, one of the world's longest sea bridges. 
The bridge is a 55km Y-shaped offshore highway linking #HongKong with #Macau and mainland city #Zhuhai. It is expected to open some time this year.
üì∑: Xinhua

A second 450kg wartime bomb was no problem for #HongKong‚Äôs police. 
Disarming and removing the bomb from a #WanChai construction site - the second bomb found there in less than a week - was a particularly ‚Äúdirty, difficult and dangerous‚Äù job due to precarious on-site conditions.
Explosive Ordnance Disposal officers cut through the shell of the device and burned off the explosives inside. ‚ÄúBomb disposal operations are dirty, difficult and dangerous. In this particular case, all three were true,‚Äù said bomb disposal officer Alick McWhirter. üì∏: Sam Tsang
#852 #WWII

It‚Äôs cold in #HongKong - but that didn‚Äôt stop this woman from taking a swim in the frigid waters near Hung Hom today.
The first day of February has been the coldest so far this winter in the city, with the temperature dipping to just 6.8 degrees Celsius.
At the peak of Tai Mo Shan ‚Äì the highest point in the city ‚Äì the temperature plunged below freezing to minus 1.8. üì∏: Winson Wong
#852 #winter

Stargazers in Hong Kong were treated to the rare sight of a spectacular "supermoon total lunar eclipse" on Wednesday night.

The full moon turned pink, then deep orange, and back again as the eclipse occured over the course of two hours.

The city was among a handful of the best-positioned places in the world to watch the phenomenon which only happens once every three to four years. üì∏: AP, AFP

#supermoon #hongkong #asia #eclipse #lunareclipse

Inside the illegal one-woman brothels in #HongKong.

Police arrested nearly 100 suspected sex workers, including 17 Russians and seven Thai transgender women, in one of Hong Kong‚Äôs biggest anti-vice crackdowns, raiding a building where flats had been illegally subdivided into more than 100 cubicles converted into brothel rooms.

The ground floor and first floor of the ordinary-looking 14-storey King Hing Building in Argyle Street, #MongKok, were used for commercial premises, but most of the flats on the other 12 floors had been converted into brothels.

Each floor had two to three flats, which were subdivided into multiple rooms and used as one-woman brothels.

Working as a prostitute is not illegal in Hong Kong, but it is against the law to solicit clients, run a brothel of two or more people, live off the earnings of a prostitute, or control a woman for the purpose of prostitution.

Visit link in profile for the full report. üì∑: Edward Wong

It‚Äôs a small #HongKong, after all. The city‚Äôs largest miniature exhibition which opened last week showcases 52 art pieces by nearly 20 local artists from the Joyful Miniature Association.

Some of the artworks met with tremendous success overseas, and will be exhibited in Hong Kong for the first time.

The ‚Äú‚ÄôFeature of HK‚Äô CNY Miniature Exhibition‚Äù runs at Olympian City in Tai Kok Tsui, Hong Kong, until February 22.  #oldhongkong üì∑: Handout

Follow @vintagescmp for pictures of classic Hong Kong.

Huangsha Seafood Market in #Guangzhou, #Guangdong province, known as the Tsukiji Market of #China, is one of the biggest markets in the country. There are hundreds of varieties of #fish and seafood scattered throughout the market.

It‚Äôs common to see five-star chefs, retailers and expats shopping for fresh and high-quality #seafood supplies there. 
One of the biggest attractions for both tourists and buyers at the market is #crocodiles, which are brought there alive in wooden cases with taped jaws so they can't accidentally bite. They are from crocodile farms in Guangdong, China, and #Vietnam.

Crocodile meat is popular in most Asian countries and it is considered a delicacy. Crocodiles weigh from 10 to 25kg and the bigger ones are about two years old. They cost around 70 yuan (US$11.50) a piece. 
Their paws and tails alone, which are most sought after, will set you back by about 120 yuan (US$19) per kg, and the tail 100 yuan (US$16) per kg. #tsukijimarket üì∑: EPA
This #elephant broke past #Chinese border guards into #Laos - and returned two hours later, over the same barrier. #wildlife #Yunnan #China üêòüöß

Today (Jan 29) marks what would have been #Taiwanese singer Teresa Teng's 65th birthday. 
Teng had a huge fan base in #Asia, singing folk songs and love ballads in #Mandarin, #Cantonese, #Japanese and #English, and scoring hits with songs such as "The Moon Represents My Heart" and "When Will You Return?"
The beloved songstress died suddenly 23 years ago of an asthma attack while holidaying in #ChiangMai, #Thailand, aged 42. #TeresaTeng #Taiwan #HongKong

Bomb disposal officers on #Sunday (Jan 28) finally defused a 450kg (1,000 lbs) wartime explosive buried deep below a construction site in #WanChai, after 26 hours of road closures, mass evacuations and a delicate operation to render it safe. 
It was only the second time in #HongKong #history that such a large bomb had been discovered in the #downtown area, and it brought parts of the district to a standstill. 
More than 1,300 residents, hotel guests and office workers were evacuated from the area. #WWII üì∑: Dickson Lee

A cold snap has resulted in bone-chilling cold conditions in #China this #winter, blanketing much of the country and famous sights in #snow. 
Several provinces received as much as 20cm of snow, causing closures of highways, tourists attractions and travel cancellations. üì∑: AFP, Reuters and Xinhua
This #dog in #China has a super useful skill. üòè

Record #snowfall üå®paralysed many areas of central and eastern #China this week. Thousands of üöÑüöô‚úàÔ∏è rail, road and air passengers were stranded as heavy snow hit several east China provinces such as #Anhui, #Jiangsu, #Zhejiang and #Shanghai, causing #travel chaos. 
Nonetheless, Shanghai residents revelled in rare snow even as the extreme weather that hit the metropolis caused a series of traffic accidents. The last time it snowed in Shanghai was 10 years ago.
China's national observatory upgraded its #snowstorm warning to the second highest level on Thursday (Jan 25). #snow #coldweather #winter üì∑: Xinhua, Reuters, Xinmin

#HongKong‚Äôs first McDonald‚Äôs opened 43 years ago today. In preparation for the restaurant‚Äôs opening on Paterson Street, #CausewayBay, two local employees were sent to #Illinois, in the #UnitedStates, and returned as graduates of the fast food giant's üçîHamburger University. ‚ÄúFellow #hamburger lovers, our days of despair are over. For the good news is that the hamburger empire is about to extend itself to Hongkong. Yes, a genuine McDonald‚Äôs is going to open at the end of the year,‚Äù ran an article in the @scmp_news on October 20, 1974.

#1975 #McDonalds #lovinit

This #train station in southeastern province #Fujian, #China, was built in less than nine hours. üôåüèº
Apart from paving the #rail, the 1,500 workers involved also installed traffic signals and a series of traffic monitoring equipment. #Longyan

#Scientists in #China have created the first #monkeys cloned by the same process that produced Dolly the sheep more than 20 years ago. 
The two long-tailed #macaques (Macaca fascicularis) named Hua Hua and Zhong Zhong, now six and eight weeks old respectively, were born at the Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute of Neuroscience in #Shanghai and are the fruits of years of research into a #cloning technique called somatic cell nuclear transfer.
Until now, the technique has been used to clone more than 20 different animal species, including dogs, pigs and cats, but primates have proven particularly difficult. #cute üì∑: Xinhua

A #Chinese man arrested for alleged drink-driving in #Harbin, #China, somehow got his head stuck between the bars of his jail cell while being interrogated by police, reports said. 
Footage showed police officers trying to free him as he cried and denied the allegation. ‚ÄúIn my 40 years, no one has treated me like this,‚Äù the man said, between sobs.

#HongKong‚Äôs beleaguered justice chief #TeresaCheng Yeuk-wah on Wednesday (Jan 24) made her first public appearance in the city‚Äôs legislature since the scandal surrounding illegal structures at her home erupted. She rejected suggestions she ‚Äúwas a person without integrity‚Äù, while skirting calls to step down.

Cheng did not provide any additional information regarding the illegal structures, but pledged to attend a panel meeting next week despite mounting calls from lawmakers across the political spectrum for explanations.

The city‚Äôs new #secretaryforjustice was embroiled in scandal from her first day in office this month, when 10 illegal structures ‚Äì including a large basement and a rooftop extension ‚Äì were discovered at her HK$26 million (US$3.3 million) home in #TuenMun‚Äôs Villa De Mer estate.

Visit link in bio for full story.
üì∑: K. Y. Cheng

You‚Äôd need a dictionary to decipher the lyrics of #Bloodfire, frontman of #Chinese #blackmetal band #Zuriaake (or Lake of Buried Corpses), with his references to nobility, virtue and #horror.

Though the breed of occult darkness their #music celebrates is unwelcome by authorities, the group are enjoying a new surge of popularity among listeners in #China seeking music that reflects their growing national pride.

Zuriaake, formed in 1998, are one of #China‚Äôs longest-running metal bands. Their name is an invented Chinglish portmanteau meaning ‚Äúlake of buried corpses‚Äù. Songs such as Desolated Mountain and Whispering Woods get audiences headbanging to subtle verses packed with dark #nature imagery. üì∑: AFP

A man in eastern #China was fined 1,000 yuan (US$150) for #painting over road direction markings to make his commute on the bus üöéquicker, an article reported.

The unnamed commuter from #Lianyungang in #Jiangsu province was caught on surveillance camera with a can of white paint and brush last November, changing arrows in a lane telling traffic to turn left instead of to go straight ahead, the article reported.

The man complained that the two existing lanes on the #highway for traffic to go straight on were insufficient and there were often delays. üò∂

#Police tracked down the man and he admitted what he had done, the article said. ‚ÄúI saw the straight lane was always packed with cars, while the turning left lane has a lot of space,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo I thought changing the signs would make my commute smoother.‚Äù The traffic signs on the road have now been changed back to normal, the article said.
Indian soldiers march during a full dress rehearsal for the Republic Day parade in #NewDelhi, #India. #RepublicDay is commemorated on Jan 26. üì∑: Reuters

Some 400 #HongKong police officers as well as staff from other government departments carried out an anti-terrorist exercise in one of the city‚Äôs busiest #MTR stations last week. 
Code-named ‚Äú#Leosharp 2018‚Äù and organised by police, the drill at #Admiralty station also involved personnel from the MTR Corporation and Fire Services Department.

A police spokesman said the drill was meant to test and enhance command and control abilities while developing frontline officers‚Äô knowledge and tactics in handling terrorist incidents.

It was also designed to boost coordination and communication between police, the fire service and MTR staff in the handling of emergencies.

Police reminded the public what to do in case of an attack: run, hide and report. #latergram üì∑: Dickson Lee

Inside the meth lab Chinese criminals set up before being gunned down by #Philippine #police.

The Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency (PDEA) said the lab in #Cauayan, #Isabela province in the far north of the #Philippines, would have been able to make 400kg of shabu (slang for meth) every 10 days, or more than one tonne a month, and was worth millions of pesos in profits.

But the #Chinese operators only made it to testing their equipment before they were raided in October 2016. ‚ÄúNinety per cent of those arrested [are] Chinese ‚Äì from the mainland or #Taiwan,‚Äù PDEA Director General Aaron Aquino said.

However, he appeared frustrated by #China‚Äôs apparent denial that its citizens were involved. Aquino recalled how they asked him to prove they were Chinese nationals. ‚ÄúI told them that it‚Äôs based on their passports and they told me that the passports are fakes and these are not Chinese, they are #Filipino Chinese.‚Äù Visit link in profile for full story.

The #Philippines' most active volcano ejected a huge column of lava fragments, ash and smoke in a thunderous explosion on Monday, sending 12,000 villagers back to evacuation centres and prompting a warning that a violent eruption may be imminent.

Authorities raised the alert level to four on a scale of five, which means an explosive eruption is possible within hours or days. #asia #news #volcano #nature üì∑: AP Photo/EPA-EFE

Japan's weather agency issued a heavy #snow üå®warning for #Tokyo for the first time in four years, urging people to go home amid fears of public transport chaos.
Scores of domestic #flights departing from and arriving at Tokyo were scrapped due to the snow while some regional #trains were also cancelled.
#Japan's northern regions frequently see heavy blankets of snow but such weather is rare in Tokyo. #Winter #Winterishere #coldweather üì∑: EPA
Woman walks into an automated carpark by mistake while texting on her phone, and gets run over by a car. Luckily, she suffered only a fractured leg. #China #watchwhereyouregoing #texting #becareful

North Korea delegation head Hyon Song-wol arrived in Seoul on 21 January to inspect venues and prepare cultural performances for February's #WinterOlympics in #Pyeongchang, #SouthKorea.
Hyon is no dourly-dressed, suit-wearing bureaucrat from the North, but the leader of #Pyongyang's most popular all-female #Moranbong Band. Nonetheless, she is a politically powerful figure as a member of #NorthKorea's ruling Workers' Party's Central Committee.
Hyon's presence in the run-up to the international event is seen by some as the North's latest attempt to capitalise on the band's appeal.
üì∑: Reuters, AFP, EPA

Photo-sharing website Dronestagram recently put together a list of its top 20 drone shots from 2017, and they offer a stunning view of our world from above.

In our selection here, photos show a woman harvesting lilies in a pond in Vietnam, gardeners picking marigolds in the morning in Thailand, and an aerial view of Dubai's concrete jungle. 
Head to SCMP.com to see the full gallery.

#photography #drone #dronephotography #aerialview #birdseyeview #vietnam #thailand #asia #dubai

62,000 people took to the streets on Sunday morning for the annual Hong Kong Marathon. 
Despite humidity having been forecast to reach a staggering 90 per cent, our photographers were on hand to capture all the action.
üì∏: Felix Wong

#hongkong #hkig #hongkongmarathon #marathon #hkmarathon

#China is ramping up security at its border city of Dandong in the northeast Liaoning province, deploying extra troops as it braces for a potential #NorthKorea crisis.
Surveillance cameras and radiation detectors are also being installed. 
The tension between the #UnitedStates and #Pyongyang has raised fears that millions of refugees could flee across the 1,420km (882 mi) border, or that nuclear fallout could hit Chinese towns. Visit link in bio for full story. üì∑: AFP

Some 210,000 people in #HongKong call subdivided units home and the number of such cramped spaces in the city is rising, a government study released on 18 January showed. 
A disproportionate number of young people were living in these subdivided units, with about 70 per cent of the residents aged below 44. Of the units, more than half are located in #Kowloon, with the most in #YauTsimMong District, an ageing neighbourhood with vast stretches of tenement blocks.
Rents for the tiny cubicles also went up for the third straight year: the median monthly #rent in 2016 stood at HK$4,500 (US$575), up from HK$4,200 in 2015 and HK$3,800 in 2014, the study said. Full report on SCMP.com.
üì∑: Reuters, SCMP
Thousands of enthusiastic college students race to the library for seats ahead of final exams in central #China. üëçüèª Some even arrived before dawn for a spot in the queue to enter.

Giant panda couple Xing Xing (first picture) and Liang Liang welcomed their second offspring at Zoo Negara near #KualaLumpur, #Malaysia on 17 January. The gender of the cub has yet to be determined as its protective mother, Liang Liang, has not allowed keepers to take it away for inspection. The #giantpandas arrived in Malaysia in 2014 on a 10-year loan from #China. #pandadiplomacy #panda üì∑: Xinhua, EPA

An aerial view of Ocean Terminal's new wing in #TsimShaTsui. The extension, which opened last December, boasts a 270-degree panoramic view of #VictoriaHarbour where the public can look out to West Kowloon and #HongKong Island on both sides. #throwback #throwbackThursday #852 üì∏: Roy Issa

Smoke and flames coming from the oil tanker ‚ÄúSanchi‚Äù at sea off the eastern China coast. The Panama-registered, Iranian-operated tanker collided with the Hong Kong-registered bulk freighter CF Crystal and caught fire about 160 nautical miles east of Shanghai on January 6. The tanker was carrying 136,000 tonnes of highly flammable ultra-light crude oil and had a crew of 30 Iranians and two Bangladeshis, all of whom are believed to have died in the incident. Chinese maritime authorities have deployed deep-sea divers to assess the wreck and plug oil leaks.
Photo: Agence France-Presse
#Sanchi #Oiltanker #China #Hongkong

Dolores O'Riordan, better known as the voice of The Cranberries, is pictured here performing at Jardine House in Central in 2007. 
She visited #HongKong that year to promote her first solo album "Are You Listening?". The Irish musician died suddenly on Jan 15 at a London Hotel. She was 46.

Ng Kit-hing, 64, is surrounded by cardboard, boxes and other sundries at the Kwun Tong Public Pier - his makeshift home for the past 18 months. 
He, along with seven other homeless, have been making the space their home but are now getting evicted by the authorities. They have to leave by Jan 12. 
With the rain and wind making it bitterly cold at the pier and no temporary shelter for the homeless in Kwun Tong, they are requesting for the eviction to be postponed until at least March.

Even then, the homeless are short on alternatives since shelters are either inaccessible or too expensive. 
Ng criticised the authorities for "treating us like trash". "The officials simply put up the eviction orders and didn't discuss with us any possible place to go for short and long terms." Photo: Dickson Lee #HongKong #852 
Click the link in our profile for the story.

With nothing more than a sense of adventure and 14kg of gear on his back, Hongkonger Tony Or set off to hike the Appalachian Trail in the United States this April. "The AT", which passes through 14 US states, is the world's longest hiking-only footpath, with a total elevation gain that is equivalent to climbing Mount Everest 16 times. Fewer than 4,000 people attempt to do it from end to end in one go, and only one in four successfully complete it. Through his four-and-a-half-month trek, Or had close-up encounters with bears and rattlesnakes, but also met strangers who extended kindness and generosity to hikers like himself. Giving up the luxury of creature comforts, Or also had to cope with conditions like "trench foot", a result of prolonged exposure to cold and damp conditions. He lost about 9kg through the physically-challenging hike but completed the trail on September 12, and is believed to be the first Hongkonger to achieve this feat.

In 1991, he set up his own production company to support young and talented film directors, and In 1994 he established the Andy Lau Charity Foundation to help the needy. ‚ÄúNo matter how humble your beginnings are, no matter how adverse the situation you are in, there is no excuse for you not to do your best or work your hardest to strive for excellence.‚Äù Lau continues to be one of the most beloved celebrities among Chinese fans worldwide.

Prominent poet Yu Kwang-chung died aged 89 from pneumonia in Kaohsiung, Taiwan on Thursday morning. The celebrated poem, whose work struck a chord with the Chinese diaspora and Hong Kong youth in the 1960s, is survived by his wife and four daughters. He also left behind volumes of poems and essays he penned, as well as poems he translated into English. As the literary world and fans lament his passing, they also look back at Yu's years in Hong Kong, as well as his hand in cultivating talented individuals who later became prominent figures in the city's literary arena, among them poet and writer Wong Leung-wo.
#hongkong #hk #hkig #poet #yukwangchung #literature

Thousands cheered themselves hoarse when they greeted the Pope. In his farewell message from the airport, his final words to Hong Kong were: ‚ÄúTin chue po yau (god bless you all)." The co-founder of tour agency Walk In Hong Kong and leader of the preservation campaign, Paul Chan Chi-yuen, has invited four architectural firms to come up with redevelopment plans for the theatre. Their designs and ideas ‚Äì ranging from an indoor sports centre to a ‚Äúhuman library‚Äù ‚Äì will be open for public viewing until December 26 in an art space near the theatre.

Memoirs of 20th-century China have grown in popularity since Jung Chang's Wild Swans was released in 1991. But "Remembering Shanghai", co-written by Hongkongers Isabel Sun Chao and her daughter Claire, departs from a conventional focus on the tragic. Inspired by Isabel's 2008 visit to her childhood home, this personal account depicts the glamour of pre-Communist Shanghai, the co-author's diaspora journey to Hong Kong and turbulent times through a cheery and optimistic lens. Isabel Sun Chao left for Hong Kong in the 1950s, living and working in the city as a cultural affairs specialist with the United States Consul General. The octogenarian is now retired. Claire, her daughter, lives in Honolulu.

Twenty-two years ago, Xu Lida brought his newborn second daughter to a vegetable market in Suzhou, China. There, he left the girl with a note: "We have been forced by poverty and affairs of the world to abandon her. ... Thank you for saving our little daughter and taking her into your care. If the heavens have feelings, if we are brought together by fate, then let us meet again on the Broken Bridge in Hangzhou on the morning of the Qixi Festival in 10 or 20 years from now."
Adopted by an American family, the girl grew up as Kati Pohler in Michigan. And while it wasn't exactly 10 or 20 years later, this year, Xu and his wife finally laid eyes on the child they were forced to give up. The story of their tearful reunion is one of improbable coincidences and lucky encounters. Read it at the link in our bio.

This year, the Hungry Ghost, or Yu Lan, festival falls on September 5. The light's on at Hong Kong's Waglan Lighthouse, but nobody's home. It must be the most romantic but least visited of the city's declared historic monuments, sitting on a forbidding rocky island southeast of Stanley that's strictly out of bounds to the public.
